Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Advanced bonding and cutting techniques for manufacturing solid aluminum parts
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is in creation of a new aluminum parts manufacturing process. Aluminum is used extensively in many industries and can used in environmentally friendly applications. The proposed technology combines next-generation laminated object manufacturing (LOM) with a novel metallic bonding process and software advancements to create solid aluminum parts ten times faster than current additive technologies. This process can produce parts faster and at a lower cost compared to existing solutions.

This SBIR Phase I project addresses aluminum oxidation for manufacturing applications in which the oxide layer between foils must be disrupted. The team will explore multiple bonding techniques to minimize manufacturing defects while maintaining consistency of thermomechanical properties. The project's three principal goals are: 1) establish mechanical testing and optical inspection methods, 2) develop and optimize cutting and bonding processes, and 3) create a sample part to demonstrate technical feasibility.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Alloy Enterprises’s NSF Phase I SBIR project, “Advanced bonding and cutting techniques for manufacturing solid aluminum parts,” demonstrated a proof of concept for a novel aluminum additive manufacturing technology. The project focused on developing the three sub-processes, cutting, inhibition, and bonding, in order to create fully-dense, aluminum parts at high throughput. The results proved successful, with full execution of all three steps  producing parts. Rigorous and rapid test methods for strength, microstructure, and composition were developed and performed for process development. The most significant advancement was the development of a  novel bonding process that can homogenize parts. This discovery significantly adds to the commercial viability of the product. Through investigating multiple methods in parallel on the benchtop, there was rapid progress in defining the operating range of each process.  The integration of these processes was further de-risked by mirroring a customer-like workflow during the fabrication of parts.

 

The work performed by the technical team was a market driven effort, aided in part by the team’s Beat-the-odds bootcamp participation. Product requirements and capability milestones were defined based on customer discovery interviews. Alloy determined that an on-demand production system capable of making fully-dense homogeneous parts has broad applications, and can offer a competitive replacement to casting methods. Further, aluminum is highly prevalent in the transportation industry with growing applications in electrification and lightweighting. The carbon emissions reduction as a result of  this technology’s commercialization in these industries can have a sizable and immediate impact on society by reducing the time-to-market of lighter weight vehicles.

 

 


Last Modified: 02/19/2021
Modified by: Alison Forsyth
